title: Landcorp in 'pretty tight situation' – English
text:
Political Reporter 
Tuesday 18 Aug 2015 6:59 p.m. 
State-owned farmer Landcorp may be forced into a big sell-off of farms as it struggles with the dairy plunge. 
There's concern those farms be bought by offshore investors. 
Landcorp's flagship project is converting the massive Wairakei Estate into the largest dairy unit in the world. But now, with the dairy price slump, Finance Minister Bill English is raising the alarm. 
"Like any other farmer they will have a pretty tight situation to deal with," he says. 
With $1.6 billion worth of assets Landcorp is the country's biggest farmer, but official figures show it made just $1 million in the past six months and that's before the full impact of the dairy price plunge. 
The Government is concerned about its debt, saying a farm sell-off should be considered. 
"If there's a need, one of the options would be to sell-down farms to reduce debt," says Mr English. 
Labour leader Andrew Little says the Government must be sure it's not selling to overseas buyers who can't add value to New Zealand farms. 
Landcorp has 140 farms and is locked into big dairy-related plans - like Wairakei, which is converting 
18,000 hectares into 39 farms with 42,000 cows. 
Currently it is a third of the way through, but with a big investment in dairy amid the falling payout, Mr English is worried. So Landcorp is reviewing the project. 
"There's more concern because the dairying payout is a lot lower and they're a fairly big dairy operator," Mr English says. 
"If it's another failure like Solid Energy then that failure sits at the feet of this Government that shows how hopeless a manager they really are," Mr Little says. 
The full extent of Landcorp's debt will be revealed in the coming weeks when its accounts are released.
